dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bright blue sky of EARTH. Then: THE LARGEST ANTENNA WE'VE EVER SEEN. A structure stretching inconceivably hig in the sky, into the outer reaches of the atmosphere--aro 100,000 feet in the air. A majestic lattice of multi-wire high-voltage tethers, studded with hardware. Towering fro earth, up through and above the cloud formations. Over TH an UPBEAT VOICE:

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: If this looks to you like something out of one of your children’s comic book adventures, then you’re not alone! SERIES OF SHOTS of the ANTENNA UNDER CONSTRUCTION over wh the reporter narrates: REPORTER’S VOICE (CONT’D) But child’s play it isn’t. This represents the beginning of a new era in celestial communications. It’s called the Gravitational Interferometer Space Antenna, or “GISA,” to those of us who can’t remember that mouthful. Its goal? SERIES OF SHOTS of WORKERS in what look like SPACESUITS. scaffolding, hanging from wires, etc. OVER THESE IMAGES:  REPORTER’S VOICE (CONT'D) To search throughout the universe for intelligent life. With the recent confirmation of so many planets capable of sustaining life throughout the galaxy, GISA may finally prove, once and for all, that we are not alone. File footage of ASTRONAUTS on SPACEWALKS. REPORTER’S VOICE (CONT’D) The antenna will allow us to listen in, across the galaxy, through gravitational waves--seen as the ultimate means of communication through space. Now: footage of MACHINES going this way and that, spinnin lattice of tethers. They’re almost like spiders on a web. Or HYDRAS, with CYCLOPS-LIKE BRIGHT LIGHTS in their cente REPORTER’S VOICE (CONT’D) Self-replicators are used for its construction. And it’s not just machines; a select few highly- trained folks from the Army Corps of Engineers will have to check every inch of the carbon fiber for flaws. It has proven one of the most demanding jobs on Earth, but these men and women are up to the task. Engineer Major Roy McBride of Las Cruces, New Mexico, says he’s not afraid of the challenge: IMAGE OF FOUR YOUNG MEN and TWO YOUNG WOMEN, seated on a SOFA, in a nondescript office environment with an Army Co of Engineers logo/graphic on a screen behind them. One of them is ROY MCBRIDE. Roy McBride: forties, handsome. His eyes are light blue, seemingly friendly, but reveal little about the man himse He is even-tempered, but one would not call him kind; the is an icy quality to him. Still, he is not overtly cruel petty, and to talk to him, one could never question his intentions or his integrity. Roy speaks slowly, formally, deliberately, as though he d not want ever to repeat himself. He seems guarded, sincer precise, competent. His face is blank but prone to the occasional awkward joke, and those jokes are made almost self-amusement. He does not seem morose. In fact, he smiles all the time, and his face often ligh with little motivation. He speaks with a very slight Midwestern/Western accent. Think Neil Armstrong. As he speaks, on the screen appears the title “Maj. Roy C McBride”.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: The Army Corps of Engineers trains us to deal with our fears. And this team here is real inspiring-- Lt. Parsegian did a repair skywalk during an episode of pulmonary edema. Now when you see something like that, you just wanna get up there and do it as good as she did. Be part of that team. So we all feed on each other in that way.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: McBride is only the latest ina long line of aerospace pioneers. His father, noted activist and educator H. Clifford McBride, was part of an astronaut colony tragically lost in space eighteen years ago. It is CLIFFORD MCBRIDE whom we’re LOOKING AT. Looks somew like Bill Clinton in that old Georgetown photo--almost li countercultural figure, a_ sharp contrast with Roy's butt down appearance.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: My Dad was...he was certainly a different kind of astronaut. He was a free-thinker. He went all the way to Neptune. It didn’t end up going the way he wanted, but he’s the reason I do what I do. I just think you can’t worry too much about the past because you don’t have control over it. So I look forward. And like I said, we've certainly got ourselves a helluva team here.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (cheerful again) That team is always on the go. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: REPORTER’S VOICE (CONT'D) In the clouds, it’s all about the work, and one gets the sense that Roy would rather be left alone to perform his duties than talk to this reporter:

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: What I want...is to serve, to do my job as good as I can, away from the spotlight. It’s real critical to maintain control and not to be vulnerable to outside factors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy flashes that smile.

dialogues.speaker: REPORTER'S VOICE
dialogues.text: With all of the risks, do you ever contemplate the larger meaning of what it is you're trying to accomplish? How we may be able, for example, to detect intelligent life out there, and find out what they might have to say to us?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: No...not really... That’s not for me to comment on--I don’t consider that sort of thing. (the smile returns) But...I do thank you for your interest in the program, and we hope your continued support leads to our success. ANGLE ON ROY as we: FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: EXT. GISA TETHER STATION — DAY The ANTENNA STRETCHES HIGH INTO THE SKY. LOOKS LIKE IT’S ALMOST DONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are inside a crowded, cramped place, where no attentio paid to aesthetics and a lot is paid to practicality. Exposed wires and computers and electronics. A circular l of “GISA” (The Gravitational Interferometer Space Antenna  Video monitors are everywhere, but so are signs of recreation: a ping-pong table, board games, cards, etc ar mixed with more high-tech gaming equipment. HANK WILLIAMS’ MUSIC is PLAYING. It’s sort of like a part atmosphere here. CLOSE ON: MEN AND WOMEN SMILING--and looking into the CAM Waving, gesticulating, clapping, egging us on. But we can HEAR them; we HEAR MERELY the Hank Williams and the SOUND WHIRRING: an AIRPACK, for a spacesuit of some kind. It is Roy’s POINT-OF-VIEW. He walks in a SPACESUIT and HELMET, in his own world. A RADIO voice breaks in, over t Hank Williams:

dialogues.speaker: RADIO
dialogues.text: (OS VOICE, RADIO FILTER)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let’s see, we got some scores for ya, Roy... It was Auburn over Georgia Tech, 35-16... Oklahoma 17, Syracuse 9... And San Diego State beat Oregon, 23-20.

dialogues.speaker: SMILING WOMAN
dialogues.text: (muffled; through radio filter) Skywalk 714! You go, boy! Roy waves, gives the thumbs up. Then:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aided by three men in white jumpsuits (the back of which stamped by corporate logos for RAYTHEON), Roy is position inside a small compartment with a LATCH. To a jumpsuited named SAL:

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: I guess there won’t be too many more of these soon, huh Sal.

dialogues.speaker: SAL
dialogues.text: Yes sir, almost done! Sal STARTS PUNCHING SOMETHING into a NEARBY COMPUTER. Roy REACHES AROUND SAL'S EAR, PULLS a GOLF BALL from behind h EAR. Roy taps Sal, who smiles at the quite nerdy trick, noddin he’s seen it before. Roy GRINS WIDELY. The STEEL DOOR SLIDES OPEN, and SAL GENUFLECTS... Only now do we realize that we've been in a STATION floa inconceivably high in the sky. Not in space, certainly earthbound, but frighteningly high up--higher than any aircraft we’ve ever been inside of. We move outside, above a small PLATFORM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in the outer reaches of the atmosphere--around 100 thousand feet in the air. The ground far below is both bl where the waters are, and tawny, where the land is. The earth’s curvature is beginning to be apparent. The air is frigid and thin, and the environment hostile. there is no doubt it is beautiful. We aren’t in space; we are still connected to the earth, as Roy stands at the station’s exterior. We cannot SEE his face, which is SHIELDED by his helmet’s dark visor. We go with Roy as he steps out of the pod and walks onto--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy BEGINS TO CLIMB DOWN a SMALL LADDER. HAIR-RAISING SILENCE. Roy looks UP. The EDGE OF SPACE ABOVE. Back down

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE, (RADIO FILTER)
dialogues.text: The earth sure is beautiful today. As always... As he MOVES, we SEE, BELOW HIM, the TETHER CORDS, NEVER- ENDING, or so it seems. And, THOUSANDS OF FEET BELOW ROY, THE EARTH. It passes below his FEET, and it’s just the mo spectacular vista. The CLOUD FORMATIONS are like Van Gogh “Starry Night,” magnificent swirls, vibrant. Between Roy and the ground is much air activity. About a dozen shuttles (mostly unmanned) crisscross below us, carrying tethers, busses, tether-deployment spools, and o building blocks for modular architecture. Some tethers ar dozens of miles long. SELF-REPLICATING MACHINES, looking like HYDRAS made of GRAPHENE, maneuver up and down the antenna. With the shuttles below him, and SATELLITES high above hi Roy is sandwiched--with a lot of space--in between. The project is visually exciting, but for Roy, it's busi as usual. We HEAR STATIC. And out of the STATIC, ROY’S

dialogues.speaker: RADIO FILTERED VOICE
dialogues.text: ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) Control, I have established visual with tether oh-niner-four-five. Please confirm it is offline. Over.

dialogues.speaker: CONTROL, (RADIO FILTER)
dialogues.text: That's affirmative, Roy. Tether oh- niner-four-five is offline.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Roger that. Roy floats down perpendicularly alongside a several-mile- long, multi-wire structure. Roy appears small, like an ant on a tree. We HEAR HIS BREATHING... He rappels down, rather gracefully. Turns some kind of a wheel that allows two parts of the tether to become attac ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) Control, I am...closing the loop now. Over. A POWER SURGE has HIT THE TETHER. Roy is STARTLED: ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) (some concern) Control, I just experienced some unusual power surges. They appear to be quite extreme.

dialogues.speaker: CONTROL, (RADIO FILTER)
dialogues.text: (alarmed, but completely under control) Uh, yeah Roy, we picked that up too. We--we advise aborting here, we uh, repeat--we do advise aborting.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Control--I have not yet completed my tasks--— Suddenly: along the entire length of the tether to which is attached, the busses’ ACTIVATION LIGHTS come on, one b one. (The lights are how we tell the structure is active. The HYDRA MACHINES START UP AGAIN!  Roy can see the tether is becoming active, section after section, at breakneck speed--and he pushes himself away f it at the last second, just as it ACTIVATES. He REBOUNDS against another, parallel (ACTIVE!) tether, I SHOCKED, as he RICOCHETS against it--changing directions- begins to SPIN out of control. He SPINS SO VERY FAST... Is he DEAD...? But remarkably, he’s able to speak--rather calmly, given situation. ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) (through heavy breaths) Control-- As Roy continues to tumble, the radio in his helmet squaw away--though never in a panicked tone: ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) Obviously a serious malfunction here--I’ve lost balance, over. ROY CONTINUES TO SPIN, CRAZILY, MADLY. VIOLENTLY. He bare avoids hitting more tethers... ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) I’m gonna try and level out as soon as this air thickens up. (beat) Control? (beat) Control, do you read? NO ANSWER. Then, as he descends: ROY STRETCHES HIS ARMS and LEGS OUT In the DENSER AIR, HE STOPS THE SPIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At last, Roy straightens himself out. Like a great skydiv HE PULLS THE RIPCORD... A PARACHUTE shoots out from the back of his suit and open with tremendous force, YANKING HIM UP and AWAY FROM US. He RIGHTS HIMSELF and begins to float safely to the earth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy sinks to the surface. A WIDE SHOT as we SEE: SCORES o PEOPLE RUNNING TO HELP HIM... MAN’S VOICE (PRE-LAP) I must say, you seem to be in remarkably good shape, Major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ROW of HOSPITAL BEDS. Roy is sitting up, on one of them Each seat/bed has a SCREEN NEXT TO IT. Large WINDOWS LOOK OUT INTO THE COLORADO WILDERNESS. A pair of MED TECHS are here, doing CHECKS on Roy. Roy sits alongside a window as they check his heart, lung blood pressure, temperature, etc. Roy looks out the windo Earth, dusk. Beautiful, with cloud formations. He has trouble keeping eye contact with the Medical Officers. A takes ROY’S PHOTOGRAPH.

dialogues.speaker: MED TECH
dialogues.text: How d’you feel?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Well...my left shoulder’s a little sore. It was likely hyperextended at some point during descent. MED TECH #1 (CONT’D) Yeah, you got yanked around pretty good. But you’re in one piece. (beat) Sad to say, some of your fellow engineers weren't so fortunate.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: (beat) What’s that, sir?

dialogues.speaker: MED TECH
dialogues.text: We lost your support crew, on the wire--and four hundred some odd more here on earth, too. Been tragic.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Gee... That’s real unfortunate. I’m real sorry to hear that...  10.

dialogues.speaker: MED TECH
dialogues.text: Would you like the shades down, Major?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: No, it’s okay. I like to observe the, the cloud patterns and the mountains. The Med Tech hears this, nods, then TYPES something into small iPad-type device, except it unscrolls. The CAMERA TILTS UP the ELECTRONIC DOCUMENT TO SEE: “MILD AUTISM”. As the Med Techs pack up, Med Tech #1 holds an earplug-si item.

dialogues.speaker: MED TECH
dialogues.text: (hands Roy the earplug) You might want to put this in your ear, sleep with it overnight. Just to check for any head trauma. And try to stay put, if you can.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Yessir. I would like to be able to return to my work.

dialogues.speaker: MED TECH
dialogues.text: [If] Your head checks out, you can be cleared to go back as soon as tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Okay. I’d like that very much. Given all that’s occurred, they’re probably pretty shorthanded up there.

dialogues.speaker: MED TECH
dialogues.text: (stares for a beat; then) Of course. Try to rest. He packs up and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy is in bed, sitting up in hospital whites. A GREEN LIG and a BUZZ to his left. He PUSHES A BUTTON. PROJECTED in front of him, a very advanced form of FaceTime is showing His mother. LEANNE MCBRIDE. Late sixties. Seems older tha her age; her face is lined, her mouth slightly downturned  11. She SEES him, EXPLODING WITH EMOTION. The sound is worse the image, for some reason:

dialogues.speaker: LEANNE MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Roy! TEARS FLOW FORTH from HER:

dialogues.speaker: LEANNE MCBRIDE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank the Good Lord! I couldn’t lose you up there too. You’re all I've got...

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Hello, Ma. I’m all right. I’m gonna go back to work soon.

dialogues.speaker: LEANNE MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: I love you--so much. I was just so sick with worry--

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: (smiles) There’s no reason for any kind of concern. The fuss is unnecessary.

dialogues.speaker: LEANNE MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Oh Lord... I know you don’t understand--you can’t. Maybe someday you will... I’m sorry you're alone there...

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: It’s okay. (beat) I prefer it.

dialogues.speaker: LEANNE MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: I love you, Roy. You’ll always be my little one. Maybe I can see you for Thanksgiving?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: It’s possible. Goodbye, Ma.

dialogues.speaker: LEANNE MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Goodbye, darling. He PUSHES A BUTTON and it SHUTS OFF the image...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is DARK. ROY is prostrate, in bed, asleep. RESTLESS. We HEAR his PULSE, HIS HEART... Roy’s EYES OPEN, and he is COVERED IN SWEAT. His EYES WID like he’s SEEING A GHOST. AWAKE, he has a VISION. FLASHING: An image appears to him, and to us: The striking eyes and most of the face of a YOUNG BOY. He seems around 8 years- old, looking off-screen at something. He's smiling and blinking, in EXTREME, STEP-PRINTED, SLOW MOTION. But the image is very UNCLEAR. It’s BLURRY, almost like a reclaimed moment from the Zapruder footage. WIDER SHOT -- again, EXTREME SLOW MOTION. A SMALL BOY (probably the same person as the one in the previous imag runs across what might be a wet, cobble-stoned street, on cloudy day. This time: A GIRL, an OLDER GIRL, is JOINING HIM. The image is haunting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The final image: striking, mainly because it's so odd. A MEDIUM SHOT of what looks like a MEDIEVAL CASTLE (!) IRON GATE, COMING DOWN, in the same EXTREME, STEP-PRINTED, SLO MOTION as in the other image. ROY’S BREATHING BECOMES LABORED. CLOSE SHOT on ROY as he then looks out the window. His pa abating somewhat, he allows his head to REST back, ON THE PILLOW. His EYES DART BACK AND FORTH, looking out to the ceiling--and to the heavens... FADE OUT.

dialogues.speaker: CUT IN
dialogues.text: INT. HALLWAY —- MORNING A YOUNG WOMAN IN ARMY FATIGUES comes down a hallway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She approaches ROY, who is dressed and sitting up. Going through a “Scientific American” on-screen magazine.  13.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN IN ARMY FATIGUES
dialogues.text: Morning, Major. I’m here to take you to SPACECOM Control. For debriefing. Is that okay?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Course, Ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It’s the center of the base. A big “USSPACECOM” SIGN. Roy is being escorted by the woman. A restaurant, a souvenir stand. MUZAK plays softly. Families are here, excited. There is a TOURISM BOARD desk SIGN READS, “READY TO MEET AN ALIEN? GO TO SPACE!”). A LA ALIEN CHARACTER, meant to appeal to children, graces the painted board: “Andy The Alien”. Two YOUNG CHILDREN get their PHOTOS TAKEN in ill-fitting army spacesuits in fron a powder-blue backdrop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy is led down a long, winding CORRIDOR until he reaches closed door.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN IN ARMY FATIGUES
dialogues.text: Would you like anything to eat or drink, Major?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: (friendly smile) No, thank you. The food’s real good in the dorm.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN IN ARMY FATIGUES
dialogues.text: That’s wonderful to hear. We brought in a new caterer last month and I think it’s gotten a lot better. And a LATCH OPENS:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is USSPACECOM’s covert ops headquarters. Present are FIVE of Roy’s SUPERIORS. HE SALUTES THEM, mumbles cordial “HELLOS” .  14. They are: BRIGADIER GENERAL FALLON, LIEUTENANT GENERAL SHARPE, COLONEL EPINGER, and a woman, ADJUTANT GENERAL AM VOGEL, who refers to a PDA-type device. Among the others here is an older man, seated SILENTLY in corner. Observing. His name, we will learn, is DR. MARTIN PEDROSA. More on him later.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGADIER GENERAL FALLON
dialogues.text: Major, I’m Brigadier General Fallon. This is Lieutenant General Sharpe, Director of SPACECOM Special Operations. And Adjutant General Vogel.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: (nods; then) Sirs. Ma’am. The DOOR is CLOSED BEHIND THEM. Actually, more SEALED THA CLOSED. Fallon motions for Roy to sit, and he does as wel As the others sit around him, he’s looking at a file:

dialogues.speaker: BRIGADIER GENERAL FALLON
dialogues.text: Please--sit down. Your profile’s certainly very interesting. You've done exceptionally well on the assessment tests. Says here-- you've got a near-photographic memory. Basic combat...space training, too--just exceptional, ‘cross the board.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: (subtly prideful) Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGADIER GENERAL FALLON
dialogues.text: (looks up from dossier) Your pulse’s never gone above 80 during any spacewalk or skywalk? Even on this most recent fall? That true?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: It’s what we’re trained for, sir. I can’t take any personal credit for that.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT GENERAL SHARPE
dialogues.text: You know Major, generally we look for people like you, people who won't let emotions or fears get in the way of a task. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT GENERAL SHARPE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: People who might be called “on the spectrum,” if you will. I do say that with respect. (beat) So you must not be surprised that we've reached out to you.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: No, sir...I expected a debriefing on account of the accident. (beat) I am surprised that Ops is handling it, but it’s certainly not a problem of any kind.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGADIER GENERAL FALLON
dialogues.text: Well, we’ve traveled a long way to see you here today. And it is not a coincidence. The full-wall VIDEO SCREEN behind Roy plays real-time ima of Fort Carson. Lieutenant General Sharpe consults his PD device. Fallon stares at Roy for a moment, then:

dialogues.speaker: ADJUTANT GENERAL VOGEL
dialogues.text: General, we’re ready.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT GENERAL SHARPE
dialogues.text: (nods; then back to Roy) Major, this is not about your accident--at least, not directly. (beat) We have...something of a highly classified nature to show you. On the WALL-SCREEN, A VIDEO begins to play. LOOKS LIKE OU SPACE. Through a TELESCOPE. No stars or anything visible. Until, tiny on the screen, blue dot. But not the pale blue dot of Earth. CUT TO: CLO SHOT. We SEE that this is the magical, mysterious blue of NEPTUNE. LIEUTENANT GENERAL SHARPE (CONT’D) That is the planet Neptune you’re looking at, obviously. Images from the Shun-Barcelli Telescope. Two days ago. This distant planet is almost all blue, with none of the organic brown of Earth.  16. It's like a shiny marble jewel, its sheen a uniform hypno ultramarine, except for a few darker streaks and a few wh smudges of elongated clouds. Unearthly, that’s for sure. Then, our vantage point moves, and we CUT CLOSER, longer focal length. We find our view of Neptune momentarily obscured by a faint, partial RING of dust and ice. An arc white. And then, an oblong object comes into view between us and Neptune. LARISSA. LIEUTENANT GENERAL SHARPE (CONT’D) This is one of Neptune’s closest moons, Larissa. The small moon is dark against the eighth planet, exhibit a mild, azure glow, perhaps the reflection of the color o Neptune. It’s heavily cratered. We gradually perceive that something odd is going on: LIEUTENANT GENERAL SHARPE (CONT’D) The degradation begins here. Followed by-- The peaceful blue diorama is suddenly invaded by a faint greenish blush that starts small as a pinprick and grows Slowly larger. All is not right with Larissa. Its blue complexion is overcome by a green blemish which spreads outwards and seems to utterly transform the moon's very substance, cracking and fissuring it... LIEUTENANT GENERAL SHARPE (CONT’D) Catastrophic destruction. The moon formerly known as Larissa becomes a color that alternates between dark green... and dark yellow... and black... and then... IT EXPLODES. IN DEAFENING SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rock and dust scatter in every direction, as gravity fail hold together the transformed matter, which now glows gre and yellow. CLOSE ON ROY’S EYES. Then we linger on this unsettling scenario, until we return our focus to the unblinking blu eye that is Neptune...  17. LIEUTENANT GENERAL SHARPE (CONT’D) That event was most likely the cause of the fluctuations we experienced here, on earth. The ones that almost killed you. And caused many other disasters on the ground as well.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: (nods ) I'd surely like to know what caused that, sir. THE LIGHTS COME UP. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL EPINGER
dialogues.text: Major, what do you know about the Lima Project? A TURN. Roy FREEZES for A SLIGHTLY PERCEPTIBLE MILLISECON

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: It was a research expedition to Neptune, sir. From twenty--I’m sorry, twenty-one--years ago.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL EPINGER
dialogues.text: Mmm-hmm. Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Its objective was to construct a telescope in order to search for signs of extraterrestrial life. My father was director. (beat) All crew were lost. As everyone takes notes, Adjutant General Vogel slides E- PHOTOS to ROY. THEY ARE OF HIS FATHER, H. CLIFFORD McBRID

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL EPINGER
dialogues.text: Do you remember how his departure affected you? It WAS a one-way mission, was it not?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: It was, sir. But the family was not told his absence would be permanent. He said at the time only that it was top national priority to gain knowledge of extraterrestrial life.  18.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL EPINGER
dialogues.text: And how did you handle that?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: My, my mother has often expressed her devastation by his abandonment. (beat) It’s the consensus that his departure was unforgivable. Roy lets loose a small laugh(!). An AWKWARD BEAT. He sobers: ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) Sir, if you’re trying to test my loyalty or fitness here, it’s not necessary. I assure you, I’m in no_ need of any kind of support in this manner. I do accept my father’s mental illness. And I acknowledge it led to the mission failure. The others look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL EPINGER
dialogues.text: Roy, we have something that might come as quite a shock to you. (beat) We've intercepted secret communications sent to Neptune, we believe from Mars. They lead us to conclude that your father and others from the Project are still alive and for reasons we do not understand, appear to be conducting some extremely dangerous experiments. About which we are deeply, deeply, concerned.

dialogues.speaker: ADJUTANT GENERAL VOGEL
dialogues.text: The last intercepted communication revealed discovery on Neptune of large quantities of antimatter, Major. Enough when harnessed to destroy the entire solar system. Roy is BLOWN AWAY; that slight smile disappears. A darkne overcomes his countenance, and he turns inward.

dialogues.speaker: COLONEL EPINGER
dialogues.text: Major?  19.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: (finally; clears throat) My father is...alive, sir?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT GENERAL SHARPE
dialogues.text: We believe so. The Lima Project’s A.I. is still online, and as you know, this would indicate crew has survived. We must ensure they can do no further harm. As such, your relationship to him is potentially invaluable to us.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Yes sir...

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT GENERAL SHARPE
dialogues.text: We'd like you to try and contact whoever is communicating with the Lima Project. We’ve determined that the signal is coming from Mars. Presumably, any message sent there would ultimately reach your father, on Neptune. We’ve tried already without success. It’s a bit of a Hail Mary...but we’d like YOU to give it a shot, find out his location and any other information you can gather. (beat) You’1ll have to go to a secure spot on the moon, of course--for a quantum connection that can’t be hacked.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Sir, in the event that contact is made, you will then...attempt to apprehend him and bring him to justice?

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT GENERAL SHARPE
dialogues.text: That is our intention, yes. Can we count on your participation? (beat) Roy?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Well sir, I--I’m just trying to understand--

dialogues.speaker: BRIGADIER GENERAL FALLON
dialogues.text: Major, have you not been

dialogues.speaker: LISTENING
dialogues.text: (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: BRIGADIER GENERAL FALLON, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your father has threatened the destruction of our entire solar system. Does that not mean ANYTHING to you?!?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Yessir. It surely does. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEDROSA, (0.C.)
dialogues.text: Roy, I’m Dr. Joao Pedrosa. About to answer, Roy turns. At that moment, the old man o to the side, Dr. Pedrosa. He speaks with a much kinder to DR. PEDROSA (CONT’D) I am currently Commander of SPACECOM lunar operations, at Tycho. I knew your father very well--we studied neuroscience together, at Purdue University. He was a very brilliant man--a true legend in the department. He looked at things his own way and contemplated vast concepts. So I can understand well his struggles-- because keeping sanity in the face of the infinite can be a monumental challenge. Pedrosa gets up, approaches: DR. PEDROSA (CONT’D) Like you, I was skeptical of his survival. But after reviewing the Neptune transmissions, I am now convinced of their authenticity. Of course under usual circumstances, you would want no part of this. But if he is truly alive, we do not dare lose him twice. Will you help us try to find him? ANGLE ON ROY. Roy looks down again, at the screen. It’s a electronic DOSSIER. (Like an old-fashioned bank file, tha opens, but its papery surface is capable of displaying digital information. Such as photos, maps, graphs, etc.) They PUSH THE FILE GENTLY TOWARD ROY. He sees his FATHER’ IMAGE in a photograph. He STARES AT IT. Roy looks back up at the men:  21.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: I will, sir.

dialogues.speaker: BRIGADIER GENERAL FALLON
dialogues.text: You depart for the moon in twenty- four hours. Adjutant General Vogel SLIPS HIM a black leather folder:

dialogues.speaker: ADJUTANT GENERAL AMELIA VOGEL
dialogues.text: All non-relevant information has been redacted. Please familiarize yourself with its contents... The sound FADES OUT as we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, bright room dedicated to preparing for space tra What looks like black leather Eames chairs, cases, men an women in white pants and shirts helping astronauts get re Roy is being fitted with his suit. Roy slides open a kind foldable iPad and places EARBUDS into his ear. We HEAR a

dialogues.speaker: RADIO VOICE
dialogues.text: Slate One-Niner-Four. Transmission Lima Project, 7/19/15. Voice of H. Clifford McBride. He is listening to an FILE. We HEAR, with RADIO FILTER:

dialogues.speaker: H. CLIFFORD MCBRIDE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: (tone: banal, scientific) We're coming to you now from our base of operations for the Lima Project. And we're going to send you images in a bit from our new Ocular telescope. Sponsored by our good friends at Brookhaven Solar. OVER THIS: ROY’S POV as: men and women prepare for spaceflight, finishing their attire--as Roy LISTENS, an I of CLIFFORD MCBRIDE comes up on his screen. It is like a Skype call gone wrong; the image is high-quality, but the feed is poor, vacillating between a still frame of Cliffo McBride and a sped-up image. The AUDIO is constant.  22.

dialogues.speaker: H. CLIFFORD MCBRIDE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now that we believe there are microorganisms on many extrasolar planets, and so many Goldilocks planets perfect for life, we ask the question, “How soon will it be before we find intelligent life in the universe?” ROY’S SCREEN now features IMAGES of SPACE, then NEPTUNE’S MOONS and NEPTUNE’S SURFACES as the AUDIO CONTINUES: H. CLIFFORD MCBRIDE (CONT’D) We are so excited about this prospect. And who really knows if we haven’t been contacted already? Who knows if our cosmic friends haven't tried to reach us through gravitational waves, or some other method we can’t fathom? We might be cockroaches walking along a chessboard, not knowing about the great game of chess! Now--I...AMa little surprised we don’t have anything yet. [Surprised by] The silence. But--I have confidence. So...thank you, Brookhaven Solar! We have many-- The SCREEN GOES BLACK. “PORTION REDACTED.” A MAN IN WHITE PANTS AND SHIRT then checks with Roy. Roy CLOSES the SCREEN. Referring to his suit:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How’s that, Major? Not too snug?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: No, it’s fine, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pre-breathe for the moon should take about fifteen minutes.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Thank you. The Man PLACES a BREATHING APPARATUS over Roy’s mouth and nose. He moves to another passenger.  23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy ascends the narrow scaffolding, with Pedrosa right behind. It’s oddly primitive; the way to the shuttle entrance is a fifty-foot stepladder which goes straight u where the LUNAR SHUTTLE awaits, nose-up. Harrowing climb most of us, but there are several people on this ladder, looking surprisingly businesslike and quotidian. A VOICE through a LOUDSPEAKER:

dialogues.speaker: LOUDSPEAKER VOICE
dialogues.text: Please use the safety straps for your wrists as you ascend. You will find them located on the rails on either side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy and Pedrosa, on the shuttle. Both men LOOK into a sma SCANNER on the side, near the seats, while stepping on a DEGAUSSING PAD. Then:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Degauss complete. The craft seems to be part of a consortium between the Ar and a Southwest Airlines-type company. A hi-tech space. Little attempt at aesthetics--most everything is there fo practicality, functionality. BANAL. A dozen or so PASSENGERS are aboard. Roy finds his seat a snaps together his restraints. ANNOUNCEMENTS are made in English and then in Mandarin an Spanish by a MALE FLIGHT ATTENDANT. Another FLIGHT ATTENDANT (a stout, warm woman) is giving everybody pills and whispering into certain passengers’ e Then, aloud, a recording VOICE:

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT VOICE
dialogues.text: As we exit the earth’s gravitational field, please remember: objects will float if not properly stored or secured.

dialogues.speaker: MALE FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: Guys--our rear passenger attendant, Michelle Grierson, was...MARRIED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The passengers APPLAUD as ROY strains to see this Michell person behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shuttle takes off and begins its ascent to the moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the moment when gravity is gone, things begin to float stray pens, paper, etc. Roy of course has followed the rules, but his NEIGHBOR, of Indian nationality and middle aged and burly, LAUGHS at his own ineptitude as his thing start to float away from him. Roy SCANS the SCREEN in the SEAT IN FRONT of HIM: MAPS of LUNAR SURFACE. CLOSE SHOT on HIS EYES as he PROCESSES the CONTOURS OF THE MOON’S VARIOUS CRATERS and other AREAS. The Flight Attendant hands out packages of nuts. The pilo makes an announcement:

dialogues.speaker: SHUTTLE PILOT'S VOICE
dialogues.text: On the left there, many of you can catch an excellent view of Petavius on the eastern limb. The moon’s gibbous period’s waning, so you can also see the Atlas, to the north. Roy looks out the window, SEES the landmarks. But also lights, signs of mining and human development/habitation. Tracks and angular patterns. Snapping Roy out of his observing, with an accented voice:

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE
dialogues.text: Your first time to the moon? Roy turns around. It’s his NEIGHBOR, across the aisle. Th NEIGHBOR is of INDIAN DESCENT.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: No, sir. I’ve been a couple times before, as a child.

dialogues.speaker: INDIAN NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: (trying to make conversation) A child! Well, it’s my first time! (laughs awkwardly; then) There's some good new restaurants I read, though. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: INDIAN NEIGHBOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm staying near Copernicus-—-they tell me that’s safe. How about you?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: My visit will be very brief.

dialogues.speaker: INDIAN NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Oh... I’m in artificial intelligence. (with enthusiasm; wanting to talk) It’s a very strange thing, you know, that we have so much technology and we keep all our systems without any real awareness. I understand why, but it’s...it’s strange, no?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: (that gentle smile again) Sir--I'd really love to talk to you, but I’m afraid I’m just not allowed. I’m real sorry.

dialogues.speaker: INDIAN NEIGHBOR
dialogues.text: Okay. Okay, no problem! The Neighbor acts like he’s not offended. But he is. The Flight Attendant then makes her way down the aisle an guides herself via a series of hoops and webbing overhead She checks to make sure everyone is fastened and happy. S is handing out PILLS. Roy takes a pill and sips a drink s hands him from a straw. SHUTTLE PILOT’S VOICE (perfunctory) As we begin our approach: in accordance with FASA regulations, we must remind you that many areas of the moon are in a state of extreme lawlessness. The United States government does not recommend travel to certain districts--please check your nearest USSPACECOM Outpost for a complete list. Thank you and safe travels. Roy SECURES HIMSELF as the FLIGHT ATTENDANT hands out A CUSTOMS FORM CARD to FILL OUT. She HANDS the Neighbor a

dialogues.speaker: FLIGHT ATTENDANT
dialogues.text: (with a laugh) Don’t steal my pen! Roy LOOKS OUT THE WINDOW to SEE: As the craft gets closer to the surface: lots of SATELLIT of varying sizes. A tether-type system that may remind us the GISA. MINING SITES, GREENHOUSES, SPACE JUNK, DEPOTS, and LIVING QUARTERS that look like they could be housing complexes i Boulder, Colorado. There are also HOUSES OF WORSHIP: a la CHURCH with an open roof (centered by a giant CROSS). LIT SIGNS ANNOUNCE CHAINS WE RECOGNIZE: McDonald's, Dunki Donuts, etc. MAG-LEV TRAINS link together various bases a neighborhoods, at extreme velocities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship adjusts its gyropscopes and turns over (e.g. in Musk's rocket designs), making a gentle landing near the army’s TYCHO BASE. The base is heavily guarded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The UNDERGROUND looks almost like New York’s Penn Station combined with an enormous parking garage and the most ban of AIRPORTS. The SHUTTLE MOVES into position, closer to a entrance. INT. LUNAR HANGAR —- CORRIDOR Dr. Pedrosa leads Roy through the corridor, which is, weirdly, wood-panelled. Or is it fake wood? There are FOUR MEN and TWO WOMEN who come from the OPPOSI DIRECTION, all talking amongst themselves. When Roy and Pedrosa walk toward them, they stop talking. Dogs roam about, smelling them and their belongings. Pedr moves to talk to some of the men and women. Roy face brightens at the sight of a dog:

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: (to the dog, warmly) Hey! How you doin’ there, big fella?  27.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEDROSA
dialogues.text: This is Major Roy McBride. As you know, he is here to help us.

dialogues.speaker: EVERYONE
dialogues.text: (to Roy) Good morning, Major.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: (looks up from the dog) ‘Morning. A WOMAN, LESLIE CORTEZ, fifties, steps forward. A MAN sta near, holding a PIECE OF EQUIPMENT that looks like a smal EKG machine.

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE CORTEZ
dialogues.text: We've kept a spot for you in the dormitory. An overnight stay will be necessary.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Yes, Ma’am. But I’m just here to do what I need to. I have my duties on the antenna, and they’1l probably be needing me soon.

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE CORTEZ
dialogues.text: Of course... Cortez leads Roy with her hand as we HEAR: MAN’S VOICE (PRE-LAP) Uplink should be ready to go in just a moment. INT. LUNAR BASE —- COMMUNICATIONS CENTER - LATER Roy and the others are in what looks like a recording stu A glass of water before him. Roy is seated. Dons a headse

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN ONE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We're preparing the connection now. Outside the booth, TWO TECHNICIANS make adjustments. Roy looks at a MONITOR before him, which gives him cues, well as technical info regarding high-rate pulse-position modulation and error-correcting codes. A RED LIGHT goes o Dr. Pedrosa approaches:  28.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEDROSA
dialogues.text: Whatever you say into this microphone will be transmitted to Mars, and then hopefully on to Neptune. The first step is to try to make contact. And then perhaps a negotiation of some kind.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Yessir. Interrupting: the CONTROL BOOTH CHIMES IN:

dialogues.speaker: TECHNICIAN ONE
dialogues.text: Point-to-point contact with the Mars signal is now engaged. Through the squawk box, Major.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Roger that.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEDROSA
dialogues.text: Depress the button in order to speak. Remember, your father may be listening.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Sir... What--what precisely is it that you’d like me to say, in order for us to achieve optimal results? Dr. Pedrosa takes out a PIECE OF PAPER:

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEDROSA
dialogues.text: We have assembled a text for you, one that we believe is appropriate for eliciting a response. It is written using language consistent with your own, utilizing data from your profile. Roy takes the piece of paper. He looks it over. Weak joke but a broad smile nonetheless:

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Maybe I should've taken acting classes! Okay...here goes... Roy MOVES to DEPRESS the BUTTON. FLICKS ON THE MIC. BEGIN

dialogues.speaker: TO SPEAK
dialogues.text: ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) This is Major Roy McBride, I’m currently on Tycho Base. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) (beat) Repeat. This is Major Roy McBride. I am currently on Tycho Base. ON THE MONITOR: as he speaks, there’s a voice print analy CLOSE ON ROY. Roy’s emotions are deeply buried as he READ

dialogues.speaker: THE PREPARED SCRIPT
dialogues.text: ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) Dr. McBride... It’s your son, Roy. (beat) Prior to this message, I believed you were dead. Our family was informed of this approximately two decades ago. We were told the stress of deep space had altered your behavior. And...as a result, US SPACECOM was forced to terminate your life support systems. However, SPACECOM now believes you have survived. And attempted contact, without revealing yourself due to fear of hacking. If this is true, I’m very much looking forward to hearing from you. I’ve always felt that it’s very important to have a true bond between father and son. We could have this bond. I do recall we would watch motion pictures together, very old ones in black and white--funny ones. And I remember your laugh even more than your face. I would like very much to reconnect with you. I will surely be able to move past any feelings of abandonment your departure presented me with. Your loving son, Roy. BEAT. NOTHING. These words have unlocked something in Roy He flicks off the MIC, stands. Any warmth deserts him: ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) Hopefully that achieves the desired result. The PREPARED SPEECH is LIT ON FIRE by a MAN, its ashes pl in a wastebasket.  30.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEDROSA
dialogues.text: Any transmission will take approximately 36 minutes, due to the distance. So we must wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy is standing outside, looks out the large window. OUTSIDE: A NEARBY SIGN WITH A NEON COWBOY, PUMPING a “THU UP” GESTURE--just like the famous Neon Cowboy from Las Vegas's Fremont Ave. Pedrosa EMERGES from the Communicati Center. A grim look:

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEDROSA
dialogues.text: There is no response. Thank you for your participation. You will be returned to the earth tomorrow morning.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: I understand. Thank you, sir. Sorry I was not of more help. The men shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: DISSOLVE TO
dialogues.text: INT. LUNAR BASE —- BARRACKS - ROY’S ROOM - LATER The room’s almost like an economy room in a hotel. With t exception being that, out the window, hangs Earth. The CAMERA DOLLIES OVER TO SEE: a half-eaten meal on a tray. Roy SITS, near a speaker:

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Confirming--shuttle 4339, moon to earth, reservation number EH77902. Last name, McBride.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Reservation confirmed, McBride, Roy C. Number EH77902. He hangs up. A beat. A TV SCREEN is seamlessly embedded into a wall. Some programming (news... sports.... something animated...).  31. The programming forms a low level of constant noise. And then: The screen CHANGES--completely BLACK. SILENCE. A beat. Roy LOOKS UP. A light, STATIC NOISE. FADING IN is the sound of: A MAN SINGING: “Hello, I must be going./ I cannot stay,/ came to say/ I must be going./ I'm glad I came/ but just same/ I must be going..." Roy looks at the SCREEN as GROUCHO MARX APPEARS. Groucho resumes singing after Margaret Dumont’s part: "I'll stay week or two,/ I'll stay the summer through,/ but I am tel you,/ I must be going." BEEP! The SCREEN GOES BLACK. SILENCE. THEN TEXT, on the SCREEN: “BRE YOU COMING?” A SERIES OF NUMBERS AT THE BOTTOM of the SCREEN. CLOSE SHOT: ROY’S EYES. Then we SEE that the screen GOES BLACK. We HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: They appeared to be coordinates of some kind, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy stands as Dr. Pedrosa and TWO MEN and LESLIE CORTEZ s around a conference table, with looseleaf binders in fron them. MOON PHOTOGRAPHS, illuminated from behind, line the walls. Chairs all around. Coffee. Roy is reluctant as he stands at attention. HE STARES STRAIGHT AHEAD, NO EYE CONTACT. The others seem STUNNED INTO SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: I believe the proper first step would be to get me to Mars, to the specified coordinates. I would of course be willing, in order to help resolve this crisis.  32.

dialogues.speaker: LESLIE CORTEZ
dialogues.text: We are very grateful to you for your service, Major. We will analyze the information you received. But you may return to Colorado now.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: No Ma‘am, I’m sorry, but I do feel I should continue to aid the mission. My father is the individual at issue here. And under the circumstances I feel I should remain involved in order to bring him appropriately to justice.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEDROSA
dialogues.text: (leaning forward) A personal connection is an unknown variable and represents serious risk.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Yes sir. However, the task itself inherently involves risk, especially as it appears you will not have multiple chances. And if it really IS my father who is trying to reengage, obviously I would be anxious to confront him. But I’m also considering the task itself, and not merely my personal views. None of them answers. Roy steps forward: ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) A situation may arise that only I am able to respond to. (beat) So for this reason, I believe I should be part of any continuing mission. Pedrosa can tell that Roy’s serious, DETERMINED. ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) (beat) Sirs? Ma’am? Do I have your permission to continue on in this manner?  33. ANGLE ON PEDROSA as we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SECURITY MEN all SURROUND ROY, like he’s the President. A POV SHOT of ROY as he WALKS toward: AT THE END OF THE CORRIDOR is Dr. Pedrosa. Over this:

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEDROSA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You will travel on a United States military craft already designated for Mars. It contains a payload of a classified but routine nature, and the crew will know of you only as a passenger--a higher-ranking officer making a visitation to the outpost. It will depart from outside standard surveillance, on the Far Side of the moon. As your participation was unanticipated, the path from our current point will take us through only recently- settled territory. We will be escorted by the United States Army’s Space Division. And I will protect you as far as I am able.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy is sitting up on a medical table. We STILL HEAR DR. PEDROSA’S VOICE. A MEDIC approaches ROY. CLOSE SHOT on an injection into ROY’S ARM.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEDROSA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Members of the crew were selected on the basis of skill and limited social needs, and as such should be no impediment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Pedrosa and Roy board a MONORAIL. As they do, we HEAR

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEDROSA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You will be contacted by a Colonel Lipset once you reach Mars. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEDROSA, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He will assist you as you attempt to communicate with your father. Your stress levels will be monitored at all times. If psychological failure is indicated, you will be removed from the mission. This is necessary due to your relationship with the target.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: My focus is entirely on achieving a proper resolution, sir. You need not be concerned. He was emotionally unfit, and I am not. They stop at a GATE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several LUNAR ROVERS are lined up, in the distance. They aren’t SLOW, LUMBERING THINGS, however; they are durable tough and fast and filled with artillery. The ROVERS WHIR and WHINE with ferocity, their engines warming up and getting ready for the trip ahead. Roy and Pedrosa enter, joining a host of MILITARY ASTRONA One of them, a cheerful, burly man named WILLY LEVANT, la forties, pulls up an interactive 3D MAP. It shows the LUN TERRITORIES in incredible detail. Roy listens intently as Levant checks his clipboard.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LEVANT
dialogues.text: Should be fine, but... We’re gonna be going through what is still technically a war zone. (looks up, w a laugh) Here we are, meant to tame the solar system, and instead seems like we've just brought our chaos. This your first time?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: (broad smile) No, sir. I’ve been to many Army- Navy games.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LEVANT
dialogues.text: (turns dark) This is serious business, Major. There’s no real way to know how any man’ll react in combat. It’s always a surprise. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LEVANT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (louder; to everyone) --Almost a full moon. The Far Side’s gonna be real black. Fortunately we should have a clean route from here to Veda. We’ve had a little problem since September with mining pirates, looking for helium-3. But our boys did a heckuva job and swept it all up a few days ago. Roy notices that Pedrosa is fiddling with the CRUCIFIX ar his neck. Pedrosa SEES Roy looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEDROSA
dialogues.text: You wish to join us, Roy? Fora prayer?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: (quietly; without any condescension) No thank you, sir. It’s been my experience that prayer doesn’t affect outcomes. Pedrosa eyes Roy for a moment, nods, then starts to pray Levant and the others as Roy prepares his suit.

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEDROSA
dialogues.text: Almighty and merciful God, who hast commissioned Thy angels to guide and protect us, command them to be our companions from our setting out until our return...

dialogues.speaker: MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Roy and the others--in full SPACESUITS--board a souped-up unenclosed LUNAR ROVING VEHICLE (LRV).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This rover is CRAMPED. Pedrosa has a smaller version of h mapping COMPUTER in front of him and he is next to Levant Levant is driving, and he makes a final consultation of t route. ON THE TOP OF THE WINDSHIELD: photos of NUDE WOMEN Like old PLAYBOY centerfolds... Roy is in the back seat:  36.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LEVANT
dialogues.text: Arright, let’s go. Veda, Sea of Moscoviensis.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO VOICE
dialogues.text: You should be clear to Veda, over.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LEVANT
dialogues.text: Autodrive engaged.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LRV departs, bursting forward with ferocity. NOTE: ALL DIALOG in this sequence will have a “RADIO FILT effect unless otherwise noted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levant is looking around with hi-tech BINOCULARS. Roy is hunched back, right behind him, watching and listening:

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LEVANT
dialogues.text: Setting two-niner-oh. The LRV traverses the lunar surface. Occasionally, the lu DUST kicks up, obscuring our vision. The SUN is SHINING, yet the SKY IS JET-BLACK. Roy turns back as the base recedes into the distance. THE EARTH IS IN THE SKY! PEDROSA POINTS TO IT, then DOWN TO T SURFACE, FOR ROY. A TALL OBELISK, made of STEEL, in the LUNAR DIRT, near the LEGS OF THE LUNAR MODULE:

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEDROSA
dialogues.text: [That is] Tranquillity Base Monument.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Surely is a magnificent sight. SERIES OF SHOTS of LUNAR SURFACE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A CARAVAN OF ABOUT TEN BLACK, ARMOR-PLATED rovers that we call the Russian name of LUNOKHODS appear on the horizon, coming toward our GUYS. The Lunokhods are driven by mysterious ASTRONAUTS in DARK BLUE SPACESUITS and HELMETS with mirrored visors.  37.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LEVANT
dialogues.text: (surprised) What the fuck is this...? (to radio) Alpha, what do we got here? (to radio) Alpha, we have what looks like between ten and twelve mining Lunokhods approaching our position.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO VOICE
dialogues.text: Roger that, Willy. We'll see if they're certified, over.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LEVANT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, gentlemen. They said they'd cleared this zone out. I’m sure we'll be on our way in just a minute. AS THEY APPROACH, LEVANT LOOKS THROUGH BINOCULARS. He DARKENS CONSIDERABLY. WILLY LEVANT (CONT’D) (beat) Uh...Alpha...we may have some problems. (beat; more heated) They appear to be armed. Possibly with stilettos. Backup requested. Roy STEELS HIMSELF. The Lunokhods are closing in on our L

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LEVANT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alpha, they are definitely assuming hostile formation-- (to computer) Engage manual operation. ROY BRACES HIMSELF. Dr. Pedrosa TURNS AROUND, points to a BOX next to Roy’s FEET. Roy opens the box: WEAPONS. GRENADES and a GUN which looks ALMOST LIKE a ROCKET LAUNC (The BLUE ASTRONAUTS in the Lunokhods brandish a weapon called a STILETTO--an electromagnet-propelled jet of liqu metal resembling a solid bar of light.) (VISUAL NOTE: LUNAR DUST PERIODICALLY OBSCURES the VISION  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LRV turns onto a route that runs adjacent to a POWER PLANT. The Lunokhods open fire on our LRV:

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LEVANT
dialogues.text: (to radio) Alpha, we’re now taking fire! WE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone bounces forward in their seats, restrained by th seatbelts. ROY ARMS HIMSELF. Ahead of them, he SEES three possible RAMPS: one to the right, one to the center, and one to th left. A FORK IN THE ROAD--the left side of the fork is closed o blocked by A BARRICADE. The LRV is headed right for it. At the last second, LEVANT jerks the rover to the right. Lunokhod’s driver can’t react in time. SLAMS INTO THE BARRICADE. The blue astronaut is hurled from his Lunokhod CRASHES through the windshield, flies through the air. Th Lunokhod flips over and over--no air resistance, so it se like it won’t stop... LEVANT struggles to control the rover, which is in a majo SPIN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OUR LRV stops SPINNING. RESTARTING, they take the left. A BULLET/SMALL ROCKET hits the back windshield, which CRA slightly. The Lunokhods are out of view now, but they’re out there. RADIO VOICE pipes in:

dialogues.speaker: RADIO VOICE
dialogues.text: COLONEL, WE DO CONFIRM YOU’RE FACING PIRATE ACTIVITY. Are you all clear now, over? Roy is LOOKING BEHIND HIM:  39.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: There’re at least two behind us--

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LEVANT
dialogues.text: (to radio) That's a negative, Hawk. They’re still out there, behind us at 140 and 220 degrees. Roy leans out. His jaw jutting forward just a bit, he see anxious to do DAMAGE, a strangely VIOLENT COLDNESS coming through here. He reaches down, takes out a WEAPON.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: (under his breath; to no one) I will handle these... He AIMS his WEAPON at the HORIZON. Then it appears. It COMES CLOSER and CLOSER! The Lunokhod is almost upon them HE FIRES HIS WEAPON. An EXPLOSION. Another Lunokhod appears on the horizon. Gains on them. ROY AIMS, FIRES AGAIN. ANOTHER PUFF of DUS

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LEVANT
dialogues.text: (surprised) Excellent shots, Major! Excellent!

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Colonel. A DARKNESS OVERTAKES US. It is PERMANENT NIGHT: THE FAR S OF THE MOON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We now reach the Far Side (i.e. the side always facing aw from Earth) and are weaving amongst Chinese thermonuclear REACTORS. ENORMOUS LIGHTS SWITCH ON in front of the ROVER

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LEVANT
dialogues.text: (into radio) SpaceCom, we’ve just entered the Far Side. We need a push in 2500 clicks! 240 degrees, 58 seconds! ROY LOOKS OVER TO PEDROSA. ANGLE ON PEDROSA, from ROY’S POV. HE IS SLUMPED FOR A BEA HE SITS BACK UP...  40.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Multiple SPACESHIPS DESCEND and DROP ORDINANCE. “Daisy cutter”-esque MOABs do their thing. It’s gruesome, spectacular, and Roy SPOTS IT looking behind him. It’s a ferocious scene, vicious and unforgiving, made all more bizarre by the utter LACK OF SOUND. The silence and carnage is astonishing. The EXPLOSIONS are beautiful and ferocious. The sky’s lit up for miles. MOONBASE VEDA is just ahead--it’s built over a massive cr and is underneath a DOME.

dialogues.speaker: WILLY LEVANT
dialogues.text: We are approaching Veda now, Major. (beat) Godspeed to you, gentlemen. Pedrosa salutes. Levant and the rest of the crew depart, unsentimentally, leaving behind DR. PEDROSA and TWO FACEL ASTRONAUTS to accompany ROY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy disembarks from the LRV, flanked by the Faceless and Pedrosa. PEDROSA and the TWO MEN BOUND DOWN THE SIDE OF T CRATER, with Roy. They reach the bottom, a LAUNCH PAD for the fusion-powere craft, THE CEPHEUS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mammoth hangar in a covert underground silo. Greenhouse other life-sustaining structures inside, too. The SILO is IMPREGNABLE, surrounded by a kind of HEAT MOAT which form giant RED CIRCLE around the PAD... ROY MOVES to a STEEL BAR. DR. PEDROSA PUTS HIS FOREARM un a BLUE LIGHT. The SILO OPENS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The spacecraft--THE CEPHEUS--is poised on the pad, glowin the beacon lights. Dr. Pedrosa REMOVES HIS HELMET and GLOVES. Roy does the same.  41. We PULL BACK to reveal the massive nature of the spacecraft/rocket. A WOMAN, SERGEANT ROMANO, approaches:

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT ROMANO
dialogues.text: Major, are you all right? We'd been told an officer would be joining us, and we heard about your trouble getting here--

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Yes, Ma’am. The chaos is real infuriating, no doubt. But we were able to engage them on their terms. Pedrosa INTERRUPTS Roy, pulling him aside. Something is WRONG; he’s sweaty, white as a sheet. Sotto:

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEDROSA
dialogues.text: Roy--please, take it-- He hands Roy a thin silver card. Roy looks at him, bewildered: DR. PEDROSA (CONT’D) (sotto) It is the redacted section of your father’s profile. The password is “daisywheel”. Examine it only when you are off the grid. The hard drive will protect you from any viral interference. Roy SPOTS BLOOD, CASCADING DOWN Dr. Pedrosa’s HAND. Looks around for help--

dialogues.speaker: DR. PEDROSA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Roy. Roy spins back around. Pedrosa grabs him, SMEARING BLOOD

dialogues.speaker: ROY'S SLEEVE
dialogues.text: DR. PEDROSA (CONT’D) SPACECOM does not trust you. Try to remain as alert as possible; do not allow them to cloud your perception. And you will be required at times to be less than completely honest--but you must, to preserve the mission and the broader truth. (beat) I have faith in you.  42.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: (ferociously; to others)

dialogues.speaker: MEDIC
dialogues.text: PEDROSA CRUMPLES TO THE GROUND. MEDICS COLLAPSE on him as ROY BACKS AWAY. Roy is SURROUNDED by ARMY, among them SERGEANT ROMANO. They pull him away from the dying Pedros Roy holds the CARD in his hand, POCKETS IT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The doors open, Roy exits. OVER THIS, we HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: A WOMAN'S VOICE, (PRE-LAP)
dialogues.text: Major McBride?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sergeant Romano hands a spacesuit to Roy:

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT ROMANO
dialogues.text: Your vitals are all here, on your sleeve. Standard. Pulse, oxygen, C02, blood pressure, and so forth. (beat) This is your Mission Commander, Captain Lawrence Blunt. (to Blunt) Captain Blunt, this is Major Roy McBride, he’ll be hitching a ride to Mars on the jump seat. Nearby, three men are donning their suits and going throu their EXHAUSTIVE CHECKLISTS. They eye Roy with varying degrees of trepidation. Focus on LAWRENCE BLUNT--early 40s, dark wavy hair, dark eyes, powerful physical presence.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LAWRENCE BLUNT
dialogues.text: Right-o. Welcome aboard. Blunt shakes Roy’s hand. CAPTAIN LAWRENCE BLUNT (CONT’D) Sounds like you went through some tough territory to get here, Major.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: We surely did. Significant force proved necessary.  43. Blunt nods. He looks through a clipboard, then:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LAWRENCE BLUNT
dialogues.text: You're certified, I’m guessing.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Yes. In EVA and spacecraft mechanics. ROY NOTICES PEDROSA’S BLOOD ALL OVER HIS SUIT.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LAWRENCE BLUNT
dialogues.text: Terrific... This’s First Lieutenant Scobee--our Mission Specialist. He refers to DONALD SCOBEE--late thirties, brown hair in comb-over. He's in excellent physical condition. Looks li old Nixon aide John Dean. He stares at Roy with his pierc eyes as he extends a hand.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: How do you do. A handshake. Scobee is COURTEOUS but tough as NAILS.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD SCOBEE
dialogues.text: Major. And FRANKLIN YOSHIDA. Mid-forties. Totally remote, taciturn, a man of science. Barely makes eye contact with Roy.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LAWRENCE BLUNT
dialogues.text: Frank Yoshida’s our Medic. And Lt. Alan Tanner is on for navigation and payload. Finally, ALAN TANNER. Early-30s. A firm handshake and muttered greeting. Roy responds:

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Good to meet all you. Roy tries to turn his forearm to hide PEDROSA’S BLOOD. A young CADET walks in with food. Blunt looks down at an illuminated SOLAR SYSTEM MAP. ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) I am headed to Helios South, on Mars.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LAWRENCE BLUNT
dialogues.text: That’s pretty close to where we’re headed. We’ve got a payload for the North division, but you can shuttle South once we’re there.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Will do. Grateful for the ride.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LAWRENCE BLUNT
dialogues.text: (re: food plate) Well all right then... Make yourself comfortable. Looks like there’s some ginger beer and farmed salmon for final meal... Roy turns to Sergeant Romano. Sotto:

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Sergeant--do we know the condition of Dr. Pedrosa?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT ROMANO
dialogues.text: Yes. Unfortunately, he passed, Major. Roy nods, then turns, looks through GLASS at the ROCKET T will TAKE HIM TO THE STARS... THE CEPHEUS... Here, as everywhere, ARMED MEN and WOMEN abound. Looks down at his hand: CLUTCHING THAT DOSSIER CARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy, in his SPACESUIT, walks with the others holding thei airpacks into the top of the rocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cockpit is aglow with instruments and screens. Roy mo past Blunt and Scobee as they are ensconced to perform fi preparations and checks. Roy STRAPS IN.

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LAWRENCE BLUNT
dialogues.text: (into the radio) Checklists complete. We are ready when you are, SpaceCom. Destination Helios Station North, Mars. Over.  45.

dialogues.speaker: SPACECOM, (RADIO FILTER)
dialogues.text: Affirmative, Captain. T-Minus 15 seconds. Ready to go. SpaceCom commences COUNTDOWN. ENGINES ROAR to life. The ROCKET SHUDDERS from the force.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD SCOBEE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Ten, nine, eight, seven, six... ignition sequence begin. We have main engine start.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LIFTOFF TEAM scrambles to get away. The Cepheus, bare held to the gantry, is ready to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great fire alights beneath The Cepheus.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD SCOBEE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Three, two, one. The Cepheus rises, shaking off its tethers.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD SCOBEE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: We have lift off... It explodes forward, hurtling around the Far Side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy fights the G's.

dialogues.speaker: SPACECOM, (RADIO FILTER)
dialogues.text: Cepheus, you are a go at throttle up. Stand by for separation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Cepheus fires its BOOSTERS and explodes forward, hurt around the Far Side with increasing velocity. DARKNESS returns to the launch pad.  46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group settles in just a bit. The distant sounds of th ENGINE are a soothing, rhythmic lullaby.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD SCOBEE
dialogues.text: SpaceCom, we are commencing CTP ingestion. Everyone TAKES A PILL which comes ejected from the consol EXCEPT FOR ROY, who PALMS THE PILL and SLIPS it into his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy looks at his fellow travelers, all engaged in checkli tasks, other mundane activities:

dialogues.speaker: DONALD SCOBEE
dialogues.text: Pilot report A one-niner, Mars trajectory... The burn was on time. The residuals before nulling- -minus 0.1...

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Captain, I think my suit’s suffered an oxygen leak. It’s going to require an epoxy patch.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE BLUNT
dialogues.text: Happy to assist, sir.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: That won’t be necessary, Captain. Thank you. I’ve got it. As Roy gets up, we SEE, to his RIGHT: “CAUTION: MANUAL BOOSTER CONTROL”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy floats in to a SECLUDED PART of the ship. He pulls ou what Pedrosa gave him. The DOSSIER/AMULET, a thin, silver card. He inserts it into a slot of a small computer that in his sleeve. Inserts an earbud. LASERS and OPTICS read his irises. SCREENS on his helmet inside display his biorhythms.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Password DAISYWHEEL. Slate 23.  47. The password and bioscan activate the ELECTRONIC DOSSIER. The dossier opens up on a screen before him--in what look like MID-AIR. ON SCREEN: “LIMA TRANSMISSION INTERCEPT: 12/14/16. UNTELEVISED CANADIAN BROADCASTING CHANNEL INTERVIEW: H. CLIFFORD MCBRIDE”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PROFESSOR H. CLIFFORD MCBRIDE, looking into the camera. Unlike videos from today’s astronauts, these are HD, flui images.

dialogues.speaker: H. CLIFFORD MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Hello CBC...Toronto... H. Clifford McBride is on a space station, but exactly wh is unclear. He looks haggard and unkempt. UNHINGED. H. CLIFFORD MCBRIDE (CONT’D) I'd like to use this opportunity to reach out directly. To my son. If you could get this to him...please... (beat) Roy... Solitude has increased my perception... I look so far into the universe here, and I see how cruel it is in its indifference... So many planets potentially suitable for life, yet as of now we hear and see nothing... I’ve come to worry that our own long-term survival is in doubt. My death is not something I fear. But--the extinction of ALL ideas, of all human expression--that is the true terror. Our consciousness must extend into the future, past any force that renders us extinct. We must commit ourselves to this goal... (beat) And so I, I... If you see this-- we're, we’re real far away. And some people haven’t been able to keep their composure... (looks down, avoiding) It’s been very difficult...  48. ANGLE ON ROY. His FACE registers that this is his father, addressing him directly--and his father doesn’t look good Roy looks down, at his SLEEVE. His VITALS. Over this: H. CLIFFORD MCBRIDE (CONT’D) I’m sure you will have a lot of questions about the choices I’ve had to make. But... Perhaps someday you’ll understand. I do miss you. I’m sure you miss me, too. ROY’S PULSE STARTS CLIMBING... So he has to stop watching before the computer redflags his bioactivity...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy takes the small stick given to him by Pedrosa and put in an airlock, adding the PILL they gave him to take. Releases the lever and sends the items into space...lost forever... A VOICE, through radio earpiece, from another part of Cepheus:

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE
dialogues.text: Major! MAJOR! Roy turns, moves to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SCOBEE and YOSHIDA seem to be in some kind of quiet panic SILENTLY attending to the equipment around them. Then Yoshida comes to ROY/US (the camera is NOW SUBJECTIVE) as settles back into the main area of the craft. Yoshida tur to Roy, with urgency:

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN YOSHIDA
dialogues.text: Major--we’re receiving a “mayday” from a craft that’s in our zone. Per regulation, it may require you to accompany Captain Blunt on an EVA.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: No--we can’t stop.  49.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN YOSHIDA
dialogues.text: (surprised) Major?

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: We need to reach Mars.

dialogues.speaker: FRANKLIN YOSHIDA
dialogues.text: (smiles, an uncomfortable laugh) Major, this is protocol. We have a mayday--

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: We can’t stop! Roy moves past Yoshida into:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy enters the CONTROL ROOM, sees that the other men have on their helmets. The ELECTRONIC BEEPING alert plays, and DATA flashes acro the main MONITORS on the bridge. Lawrence Blunt to the radio, with RADIO FILTER:

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE BLUNT
dialogues.text: Ninety-seven hundred kilometers away, on the proximity alert. ROY LOOKS OVER THEIR SHOULDERS TO SEE: on a panel screen: image of THE VESTA IX. A small, rotating station orbiting “Earth’s second satellite,” the asteroid called TORO. Roy agitated:

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: The Helios Station is the destination, Captain--why are you stopping?

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE BLUNT
dialogues.text: We have a mayday, major--this is standard-- (INTO COMMS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vesta Nine, this is Cepheus Seven, United States Armed Forces Space Division. Do you read, over? Roy looks impatient, unsure how to press the case:  50.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Other craft will be in the vicinity. We have our destination.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE BLUNT
dialogues.text: (confused) Major, with respect, we're obligated to stop. As you are merely a passenger, I’m not sure I comprehend your position. Unable to reveal anything, Roy turns away as Tanner looks through flight information:

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TANNER
dialogues.text: The craft is registered as Norwegian, the Vesta Nine, orbiting asteroid Toro. Registered for biomedical research. On another screen: A scan of the Vesta IX appears. And on another SCREEN, ship schematics.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE BLUNT
dialogues.text: (INTO COMMS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vesta Nine, do you read, over? Still nothing. Roy looks at a screen for information. Eye the SCHEMATICS for the VESTA NINE.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE BLUNT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Vesta Nine, according to the Outer Space Treaty we are responding to your distress call. (beat) Do you read?

dialogues.speaker: ALAN TANNER
dialogues.text: I just accessed their log. Last transmission was Sept. 17, 13:37 PM.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE BLUNT
dialogues.text: (to Command) Command, I’m going EVA. Possible forced entry required. (to Roy) You're the only non-essential member of this craft. As you know, protocol is for you to come along. (beat) Will this be a problem?  51. Roy thinks for a moment, then, with thinly-veiled anger, starts to suit up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy and Blunt strap on equipment and make final suit augmentations for their EVA. Roy SEES Blunt is ARMING A WEAPON, a GUNLIKE object.

dialogues.speaker: LAWRENCE BLUNT
dialogues.text: (stares at Roy for an uncomfortable moment; then: ) I'd advise you to arm yourself as well. You’re no longer ina predictable environment.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: (curt) I’m aware of that. Frustrated, Roy turns, looks through GLASS to SEE: the Ve IX, about the size of the Cepheus, slowly rolling in plac We hear Donald Scobee from the cockpit...

dialogues.speaker: DONALD SCOBEE, (RADIO FILTER)
dialogues.text: Heading three-three-four. Cannot confirm live contact. Range three- zero-seven-zero meters and closing. (beat) Reactor is still hot. (beat) Optimum approach angle, thirteen degrees. Coming around to three- three-four. Blunt leads Roy towards the hatch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy and Blunt stand before the airlock doors... which ope into space. Out they go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few glittering LIGHTS distinguish the Cepheus from abso darkness. Roy and Blunt jet towards the Vesta Ix.  52.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They venture away from the Cepheus and frighteningly into deep space. The Vesta is still distressingly far... And yet, the Vesta gets closer... And closer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then they are upon it! Roy reaches the airlock first. He PUNCHES BUTTONS on the DOORFRAME, to no avail. STATIC NOISE. Blunt motions to Roy, who uses a GATLING GUN to bl open the airlock. In SILENCE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy and Blunt enter the craft, pulse weapons at the ready No one’s in sight.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD SCOBEE, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, one of you is required to find the flight recorder box. Blunt points to Roy, and he and Roy move in different directions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy floats through the craft--it’s vacant, jammed with id instruments, empty console chairs. It’s quiet, except for electrical HUM. We HEAR:

dialogues.speaker: CAPTAIN LAWRENCE BLUNT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Vesta, this is Cepheus, responding to your mayday signal... Do you read...? The ZERO GRAVITY renders a lot of things floating: PENCIL NOTEBOOKS, EQUIPMENT, LIT FLASHLIGHTS. They spin in the craft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy floats deeper into the craft. It’s dark. Roy scans hi TRACKING DEVICE from side to side. The SPINNING FLASHLIGH illuminate spots for brief moments. Roy grabs one as it moves.  53. By the looks of the LAB EQUIPMENT, it appears the craft performs research on viruses and diseases. Roy continues... INT. VESTA IX —- PASSAGEWAY Roy MOVES towards an OPENING that leads to a DECK. LIGHTS are coming from that area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Much CLUTTER here, lots of ITEMS floating around. Roy moves silently. A SCREEN COMES ON. A bearded man, grizzly and haunted. A NORWEGIAN ASTRONAUT:

dialogues.speaker: NORWEGIAN ASTRONAUT
dialogues.text: This is a eulogy for 12 good men... Men who came to space to advance scientific understanding of the universe. But... Our supply generator has failed... We can no longer see the earth--and it is not visible from our current perspective... No more earth. And we are adrift, without purpose... With no hope in sight, we have decided to do the only logical thing... Then: something weird... CRIMSON ORBS are floating here a there. There must be at least a dozen. Most are baseball- sized, some are larger, some smaller. ROY touches one. Liquid. He removes his finger, the orb divides into smaller orbs. Then-- Something else is FLOATING TOWARDS US... A larger MASS... ROY backs up-- AND bumps into a BODY. A dead body. He is startled. Roy pushes past them. MORE DEAD bodies ahead. One body leaks BLOOD, which bubbles out of the man's torn suit, up, down and around, in every direction, forming th crimson orbs.  54.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Cepheus, I have one expired individual here, no signs of anyone alive. I believe I’ve viewed a suicide video file of some kind.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD SCOBEE
dialogues.text: Copy that, Major. Uh, Major, we've momentarily lost contact with Captain Blunt here.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Appears I have as well. Will attempt eye contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Roy is in the aft of the ship and is DOWNLOADING informat from a central computer shaft. PULLS OUT a BLACK BOX from the console. A small LIGHT on Roy’s tracker FLASHES.

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE, (RADIO FILTER)
dialogues.text: Captain? No ANSWER. Roy tenses, looks around. Starts to float in that directi Roy moves between cramped rows of SHADOWED EQUIPMENT. There’s MOVEMENT in front of him. He hesitates. Then, another shadowy movement...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROY MCBRIDE (CONT’D) Captain Blunt? Again, no answer! Roy RAISES HIS WEAPON. MOVES FORWARD TO

dialogues.speaker: AROUND THE CORNER
dialogues.text: We SEE a truly GROTESQUE SIGHT: a BABOON DEVOURING CAPTAI BLUNT’S FACE! It’s a big one, a Chacma, close to 100 pounds. It’s insan and hungry. Roy jumps back, beyond startled.  55. ROY’S P.O.V. -- The baboon SEES ROY, SHRIEKS (LOUDLY--but SILENT TO US because of our helmeted P.O.V.). It knocks o some equipment as it swims toward us in the gravity-free space, floating towards ROY’S jugular. BANG! ROY KILLS THE PRIMATE WITH HIS WEAPON. It TUMBLES AWAY, dead. Roy comes over to help. He looks in what remains of Blunt eyes. The pupils are not dilating. Roy PUNCHES a BUTTON o the SIDE OF HIS HELMET. OUT OF BREATH:

dialogues.speaker: ROY MCBRIDE
dialogues.text: Cepheus, a research primate has attacked the captain. He’s critically injured. Suggest retrieving the VDR and moving the Captain to the Cepheus as soon as possible. Please advise.

dialogues.speaker: DONALD SCOBEE
